In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date)
    error("Cannot use Date type. Use DateTime instead.")
end
```
The function `timezone_bumper` takes a DateTime and an optional Int as arguments. The default value of the bump argument is 3 hours. If you call it without specifying the second argument, it will increase the timestamp by 3 hours.

If you pass in a Date type instead of a DateTime, it throws an error saying "Cannot use Date type. Use DateTime instead."
